Bryan,

Derek and Joe make some good points.  I'd like to add one other 
thing about parameter tweaking which is that sometimes you can look 
at the bigger picture of exploitation vs. exploration as a guide to 
how to tweak the parameters.  For example, if you find your 
population converging prematurely, you may want to increase 
mutations powers or rates, or make selection less strict, i.e. be 
more explorative.  On the other hand if you can't make any progress 
you may want to be more exploitative.  Elitism is also a kind of 
exploitation.  Also, it's always good to check whether the number of 
species is generally stable and species have a healthy size.  

ken

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "Bryan Adams" <bpadams@m...> wrote:
> 
> Hi:
> 
> I'm currently working on a modification to NEAT (using a genetic
> regulatory network to create a more flexible genome), and I had a
> question about parameter settings.
> 
> I'm starting by benchmarking the system with the XOR test, and I 
have
> reproduced the original NEAT results (solutions in an average of 
3600
> evaluations over several hundred runs).  However, when I add some 
new
> code, I'm faced with the problem of not just setting my own new
> parameters, but potentially changing the standard NEAT parameters.
> 
> My question, then, is this: how do you set the parameters that 
govern
> the NEAT system?  I've played with mutation rates (especially
> structural), speciation settings (including dynamic thresholding), 
and
> the other odds and ends (popsize, minimum size for elitism, 
fraction
> of parents to reproduce, weight caps), but I'm not always sure what
> I'm looking for when I make changes.  What, aside from a solution, 
are
> the variables to look for when evaluating the quality of a run?
> 
> And I will provide bonus stars for anyone who has a non-ad-hoc
> approach to setting some of these variables.  :)
> 
> I appreciate any thoughts or suggestions,
> 
> --Bryan
